I have a book that I use with my kids titled "The book of potentially catastrophic science 50 experiments for daring young scientists". The book provides a brief summary of different techniques/inventions in a chronological order from a caveman swinging a club to Einsteins atom and to the large hadron collider along with at home experiements you and the kids can conduct. Its a great read and you are synonymous with this book now. Thanks for making me smarter every day Destin! -Travis

Do NOT donate to the ALSA! 7% of your money goes towards research while 10% goes towards salaries to those running it and 18% goes to advertisement. "Not for profit" just means they don't pay taxes! (You can find their financial summaries on the ALSA's website)

Sadly many charities are like this, but there are also many that actually allocate 100% of your donations towards their cause. Such as; The Salvation Army, Make a Wish, St. Jude Research Hospital, The American Legion, etc.

Some other "charities" to avoid; The American Red Cross (where the president and CEO Marsha J. Evans salary for the year was $650,000), GOODWILL (CEO and owner Mark Curran profits $2.3 million a year, no money goes to help anyone), UNICEF (CEO Caryl M. Stem receives $1,200,000 per year, less than 5% of each donation goes to the cause), and the ALSA.

Look up where your money is going before you donate!

You could've just tested the reaction time by clapping your hands. You get the visual cue from when your hands meet and you get the reaction / head turning of the animal. minus the time it takes for the sound to propagate to the animal, which you can easily calculate based on distance, you get the exact reaction time from when the sound meets the subject's ear to when they react. You can also test if the visual sense causes a quicker reaction (making a light switch on and see when the animal reacts.

Also you should make sure to separate between reaction time and reflex time.
